utterances: What's Krosno like?
Krosno is great.
It's really small.
It's about 50,000 people.
It's kind of a young town, too - lots of high school students.
But they get excited about basketball.
So that's good.
I'm going to guess you're pretty well-known in town already.
Yeah.
So myself and our other Americans - we kind of feel like aliens, sometimes, walking around, being African-American.
We don't see many other black people.
In fact, I really haven't seen any other than myself and Royce, my teammate.
But people kind of know who we are.
And everyone's really friendly.
Last time we spoke, you were thinking about starting a podcast.
I wonder if you've gone down that road in any way.
I'm actually at a friend's house.
I have many friends.
I've made connections all across the country in that way.
That this isn't his child, even though she says that it is.

And the Inquirer had a huge story, which a lot of people bought - got the wedding postponed when they talked about her being in jail for welfare fraud, for, you know, dating drug dealers, just the sort of background that I think nobody knew she had, and particularly Usher.
And always his mother has never liked her.
And because of, you know, her - he fired his mother as a manager and basically, all these people that he's had around him for years.
So, you know, he's always sort of had, you know, unsettling sort of, you know, aura just because she's so much older than he is.
You know, she's like 39.
Usher's like 27.
So, I mean, a lot of things sort of pointed to - I don't know if this is actually going to work.
So I think nobody was really that surprised when it was cancelled.
But now they're saying they're still together and they will get married.
It will just be later on.
So I think…
Does that have anything with all the haters out there, their sort of age difference or…
Well, you know, because, you now, you see Demi Moore and her husband, Ashton Kutcher.
I'm saying it works.
But I think what upset people the most was that he fired his mother.
He fired all the people that had been around him for years.
And whenever, I think - particularly for African-Americans -when you ditch your mother, I think that always…
Don't go there, huh?
Yeah.
That just doesn't work out well.
And I guess - is there any way to know if any of this is true?
Has anything come up since the weekend that's indicated…
Whether it's true or not?

No, just that you've seen, you know, these sort of carefully orchestrated photos of them walking together, holding hands and, you know, there were some speculation that Usher called the photographers to come out when they came out of the hotel.
I mean, just things that make you just sort of go, hmmm, is this for real or not?
So I think we just sort of have to wait and see how this plays out.
And there's been a lot of manipulation back and forth.
Both of them have addressed the press directly and…
Right.
And that's been interesting because I think it's only made it worse.
You know, him sort of asking the bloggers to leave her alone and asking, you know, Tom Joyner, even when Tom Joyner asked them to sort of stop making fun.
And of course, as soon as he hung up, they made fun of him.
You know, so it's sort of like, you know, what are you actually thinking?
You can't stop people from talking.
It's just not, you know, it's not going to happen.
So, I'm going to go on to some lighter news here.
There is a new movie out, ""Who's Your Caddy?"" It's from Black Entertainment mogul Bob Johnson.
It's his first, and it stars rapper Antwan Andre Patton a.k.a.
Big Boi and hip-hop star from OutKast.
And it's about a hip-hop star who wants to join an exclusive country club.
(Soundbite of movie ""Who's Your Caddy?"")
They're turning this golf course…
Unidentified Man #1: One of us has to go.
Unidentified Man #2: How you want to handle it?
Unidentified Man #1: My team wins, you go.
Your team wins, I go.
Unidentified Man #2: I'm going to talk to Johnnie Cochran about this.
Unidentified Man #1: He's dead.
Unidentified Man #2: Oh, wait a minute, you killed Johnnie Cochran?
…into their kind of club.
Unidentified Man #1: (Unintelligible).
I want to do it.
I feel it.
Unidentified Man #1: There you go.
What's up?
Unidentified Man #1: That looks scrumptious.
I like country clubs.
Now, this movie came out last week.
And, so far, it's earned around $3 million at the box office.
Not too bad.
I mean, could this be any worse than Will Smith's ""Legend of Bagger Vance"" in terms of black golf movies go?
Oh, it's worse.
I mean, you know, this is definitely.
I mean, it's sort of - it's disappointing and Bob Johnson with Black Entertainment Television.
You know, he had so much criticism because those, you know, the programming he had on that was not necessarily positive.
And for him to go his separate ways and now have a film company and make this type of movie, which just has no - it's not funny.
I mean, the Johnnie Cochran joke, that's not funny.
And I just sort of wonder, he's such a smart guy.
I really had hoped when he sort of made that, you know, the next step, the next step he took would be something where he would actually put something of quality out.
He did a movie at Black Entertainment a couple of years ago called ""Once Upon a Time When We Were Colored."" And the title was a little off-putting, but it was an excellent movie.

And, you know, I really had hoped from that point that - the movie didn't do well, and I think that's why he sort of stepped away from doing sort of those historical type movies, because it was, you know, back in the '50s.
But nonetheless, it was something of quality.
But this movie is just - it's buffoonish in many ways.
You know, you'd look at it and you're just sort of going this isn't funny.
And $3 million isn't that great, because if that's how much it made the first week, it's only going to get worse, you know, in the second week.
So did any of the supporting casts help?
I know Faizon Love was in it, and did that carry the movie in any way?
No.
I mean, you look at - you know, even with OutKast when they did ""Idlewild,"" that didn't help that they were in it.
So I think people can see quality.
And if it, you know, it's one thing to be funny, it's another thing to sort of be stupid.
And I think that, you know, the audience knows the difference that's why they didn't support it.
Well, the thing everyone knows about Johnson is that he's always been about business.
And was this a good business move?
Well, she's been into interior design and fashion.
So she's doing a lot of interior designs.
She actually - when there was a chance of the Olympics being in New York, she actually designed a guest room for it hoping, you know, that she would be chosen as the designer for that.
But, you know, it went to London.
But nonetheless, she's basically going to all these different smaller offices, and just using her sort of creative skills because she's, you know, been to design school.
She's about to graduate from fashion school to sort of, you know, sort of sell her product.
And she actually is pretty good at it.
But I think the interesting thing about both of the sisters, they both were sort - the father was criticized for them doing too many different things and not playing in enough tournaments.
But if you would think about it, Venus is now 27, and she's still at the top of her game.
And I think that's because they pace themselves.
They've not played in every tournament so they're not, you know, tired.
They're not, you know, totally worn down.
They actually have a freshness to them.
And I think a lot of that is because they do do other things outside of the world of tennis.
And so they don't get bored with it.
Like, you know, most of the athletes, you know, three or four years of playing every tournament, they're gone out of the game by 25.
And you barely see them with a backup plan.
Thank you.
But they have so many different, you know, sort of things.
They're very smart girls.
And I think, you know, the interesting thing about Richard Williams is that, you know, say what you will about him.
He had a plan and it actually has worked.
Venus also, which most people don't realize, for Wimbledon, she fought, for women, this year to get the same prize money as men.
And this is the first year that's happened.
And it was, you know, according to the, you know, association - tennis association, it was really because of her.
She stepped in.
She really sort of made her complaint vocal.
And, you know, because of that that was changed.

So it's interesting to see them grow up from - because I interviewed them when they were, you know, just teenagers and to see them now become this very, you know, business-like women is really a wonderful thing to see.
And, you know, we actually did talk about - talked to James Blake, an African-American player, top rank for men's tennis about race and sort of dealing with that on the court.
And I was wondering if she talked any about that, especially fresh off this win.
Well, I asked her because her father had said after Wimbledon that, you know, nothing's changed - 50 years later, nothing's changed for African-Americans.
And her thought was that, you know, her father and her mother both come from the South, so the understood that, you know, they see things very differently.
But her feelings that things have changed, they're not where they need to be, yet, but she definitely has sort of noticed the changes.
Even being on the tour for the years that she has, that people are certainly more accepting of she and her sister.
Actually, you know, enjoy watching them win.
She feels like, you know, they get 100 percent support from, you know, African-Americans and non-African-Americans and their, you know, sort of tournaments or whatever.
So I think she had a very positive sort of outlook.
And, you know, she dates men of all different colors.
She talked about that.
Her boyfriend now is European.
And, you know, she said that, you know, you have to get love where you can find it.
So I think they have a very open-minded approach to life, and I think that's because they've been exposed to so much for so many years.
And we've all watched them grown up all this time…
Yes, definitely.
…so that's good to hear.

Well, I have one other thing I wanted to ask you about, which is Sudanese model, Alek Wek, who has a new book coming out and that's titled ""Alek: From A Sudanese Refugee to International Supermodel."" She's kind of like the Williams sister of the modeling world.
I mean, she has graced a lot of covers that black models haven't before or it's very rare.
Can you talk about what is she like?
She is (unintelligible) to know that she's been through such an amazingly hard life, given, you know, given her childhood.
She has such a happy, you know, sort of spirit that I think is just, you know, amazing, given everything she's lived through.
And she has such a connection to that past.
And I think the book is a way for her, and as she said to me, a way to find closure because she, you know, in doing interviews, you do bits and pieces of your life.
But the book was - well, she was able to sort of put it all together.
And I think she also was able to talk to her mother.
We had not talked about it a lot because it was too painful.
And she was able to get her mother to sort of open up about what she had gone through and what she saw as an adult living through this in trying to get her children out of that country.
So I think this, you know, just watching her over the last couple of years, and seeing her sort of become this businesswoman, as well, because she has a handbag company.
